name: Marduk
titles: Wielder of the Tablet of Destinies
description: Supreme god of Babylon, slayer of primordial chaos, creator of the ordered cosmos, and wielder of the Tablet of Destinies. Marduk embodies divine kingship, cosmic order, and the triumph of civilization over chaos.

keyMyths.title: The Enuma Elish - Rise to Supremacy
keyMyths.summary: When Tiamat threatened to destroy the younger gods to avenge Apsu, none dared face her except Marduk. He demanded kingship in exchange for saving them. Armed with winds and weapons, he defeated the chaos dragon, split her body to create heaven and earth, and established cosmic order.

keyMyths.title: Creation of Humanity
keyMyths.summary: After defeating Tiamat, Marduk created humanity from the blood of Kingu (Tiamat's consort) mixed with clay, so humans could serve the gods and relieve them of labor.

keyMyths.title: The Fifty Names
keyMyths.summary: The gods bestowed fifty names upon Marduk, each representing an aspect of his supreme power and absorbing the attributes of earlier Sumerian deities (An's authority, Enlil's executive power, Ea's wisdom).

festivals.name: Akitu
festivals.description: Most important Babylonian festival reenacting Marduk's cosmic victory. The Enuma Elish was recited in full. The king underwent ritual humiliation and renewal, symbolically receiving kingship from Marduk annually. Culminated in sacred marriage ritual and procession along the Processional Way.

historicalContext.politicalSignificance: Marduk's rise from local Babylonian deity to supreme king of gods parallels Babylon's political ascension to supremacy in Mesopotamia. The Enuma Elish legitimizes Babylonian hegemony by placing their patron deity at the cosmic center.
historicalContext.synthesis: Marduk represents a synthesis of earlier Sumerian deities - combining An's supreme authority, Enlil's executive power, and Ea's wisdom into one supreme being.

alternativeTheories.summary: Sitchin identified Marduk with hypothetical planet Nibiru with 3,600-year elliptical orbit. Interprets the battle with Tiamat as planetary collision that formed Earth and asteroid belt.
alternativeTheories.evidence: Divine weapons (winds, net, arrow) interpreted as gravitational forces and moons of approaching planet
alternativeTheories.academicView: Mainstream Assyriology views Enuma Elish as theological and political literature, not astronomical encoding

alternativeTheories.summary: Weapons described in Enuma Elish may represent scalar electromagnetic weapons and plasma-based technology capable of planetary-scale destruction
alternativeTheories.evidence: Cross-cultural parallels of storm gods wielding catastrophic power (Indra's Vajra, Zeus's thunderbolt, Thor's Mjolnir)
alternativeTheories.interpretation: Suggests deliberate warfare rather than natural cosmic events
